page.title: 07MEMORIES OF WOODSTOCK
page.content: Mrs Clothier has lived in Woodstock all her life. She went to Woodstock Primary School when boys and girls were taught in separate classes. The teachers were very strict. She left school at 14 and worked as a dairy maid at Blenheim during World War 1. After the war she worked as a secretary in her grandfater's glove factory. She enjoyed working there very much. There were about fifty employees. The length of time it took to make a pair of gloves, varied. The Clothiers made gloves for sportsmen. The men cut the gloves from a pattern whilst ladies sewed them together on machines. The leather was stiff to cut. Many gloves were cut out at the factory and sewed together by out-workers in their homes in the villages. Mrs Clothier said one person could make two or three pairs of gloves a week.
